element.name: Chaos Domin
element.source: The Vandersnitch Guide to Races and Cultures

description.p: Gods whose portfolios include the Chaos domain govern freedom, rebellion, and self expression. They include gods of storms and natural disasters, some elemental gods, gods of fae, artistic expression, and rebellion from unfavorable governments. In some pantheons, a god of this domain are ancient but generally quiet, preferring to mingle in the affairs of mortals only enough to bring the winds of change. Chaos gods send their clerics to inspire righteous fury in the common folk, either to encourage those people to bring about a great change or to encourage them to offer sacrifices to ward off an unforseen disaster.

element.name: Blessing of Chaos
element.source: The Vandersnitch Guide to Races and Cultures

description.p: At 1st level, you gain the choice of learning either eldritch blast or viscious mockery cantrip if you do not already know them.

element.name: Chaos Surge
element.source: The Vandersnitch Guide to Races and Cultures

description.p: At 1st level, you confuse and disorient attackers. When a creature within 5 feet of you that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to cause the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. The Creature takes 2d8 Psycic or Force damage on a failed saving throw and is stunned until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the target only takes half of the rolled damage, and is not stunned.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

The Creature takes 2d8 Psycic or Force damage on a failed saving throw and is stunned until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the target only takes half damage, and is not stunned.

element.name: Channel Divinity: Destructive Glee
element.source: The Vandersnitch Guide to Races and Cultures

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to wield the power of the chaos with unchecked ferocity.
When you roll psychic or force damage, you can use your Channel Divinity to deal maximum damage, instead of rolling.

sheet.description: When you roll psychic or force damage, you can use your Channel Divinity to deal maximum damage, instead of rolling.

element.name: Forceful Strike
element.source: The Vandersnitch Guide to Races and Cultures

description.p: At 6th level, when you deal force damage to a Large or smaller creature, you can also push it up to 10 feet away from you.

sheet.description: When you deal force damage to a Large or smaller creature, you can also push it up to 10 feet away from you.

element.name: Divine Strike
element.source: The Vandersnitch Guide to Races and Cultures

description.p: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 psychic damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to 2d8.

sheet.description: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 psychic damage to the target.
Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 2d8 psychic damage to the target.

element.name: Faeborn
element.source: The Vandersnitch Guide to Races and Cultures

description.p: At 17th level, you have a flying speed equal to your current walking speed whenever you are not prone.
